comments.raw_text:
User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:2.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:2.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0

in the attached URL you can see a table that contains several check boxes.
If you try pressing on these check boxes you see that they don't respond. the same is with the links to the left of the check boxes.

I have discovered that the problem is connected to a css definition in the css file located in: http://agora.co.il/tests/myObjects.asp_files/myObjects.css

the definition is:

#content{
display:inline;
float:right;
float:none;
}

you will see that if you disable the float:none, this bug vanishes.

This bug appears only in FF4.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1.enter the page
2.click the check box or link
3.see that they don't work
Actual Results:  
the check box or link don't work

Expected Results:  
the check box or link should work like in every other browser

comments.text:
Last good nightly: 2009-11-01 
First bad nightly: 2009-11-02

Pushlog: http://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/pushloghtml?fromchange=736619af9701&tochange=00924c08d33d

Few things that stand out...

Boris Zbarsky — Bug 501847 part 4. Change frame construction to create {ib} splits that have blocks wrapping runs of block kids and inlines wrapping runs of inline kids instead of wrapping all kids from the first block to the last block in a single block. r=tn,dbaron,roc
http://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/rev/822ba7ef29bb

Boris Zbarsky — Bug 501847 part 6. Simplify MoveChildrenTo now that it doesn't have to deal with float reparenting. r=tn,roc
http://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/rev/0f12f3edad42

(Just a guess, other changesets in that range)

Provisionally CCing Boris.

comments.creator: bzbarsky@mit.edu
comments.text:
Created attachment 521372
Really clearly showing the problem
comments.author: bzbarsky@mit.edu

comments.raw_text:
So the change from bug 501847 just made the boxes for the site look more like the ones in my last two testcases.

roc, the problem here is that the anonymous wrapper div is position:relative (because it's supposed to follow along when the inline is positioned), which affects z-indexing...  In particular, it and hence its kids end up higher in the z-index than floating kids of the inline.

What I can't tell offhand is what the right behavior is.  CSS 2.1 Appendix E is defined in terms of elements, but it's not clear to me in an {ib} situation with a positioned inline whether the block kid is supposed to be in the inline's stacking context (which is what we do) or not.
comments.author: bzbarsky@mit.edu
comments.text:
So the change from bug 501847 just made the boxes for the site look more like the ones in my last two testcases.

roc, the problem here is that the anonymous wrapper div is position:relative (because it's supposed to follow along when the inline is positioned), which affects z-indexing...  In particular, it and hence its kids end up higher in the z-index than floating kids of the inline.

What I can't tell offhand is what the right behavior is.  CSS 2.1 Appendix E is defined in terms of elements, but it's not clear to me in an {ib} situation with a positioned inline whether the block kid is supposed to be in the inline's stacking context (which is what we do) or not.

comments.text:
User Agent 	Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64; rv:49.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/49.0
Build ID 	20160522030240

I tested this on latest Nightly:

a) "Minimal-ish testcase" - the text is bellow the checkbox (same on Chrome and IE 11).
b) "Even simpler" testcase - the text in on the right side of the checkbox (same on Chrome and IE 11)  
c) "Really clearly showing the problem" testcase - the checkbox is not visible (same on Chrome and IE 11).

Considering other browsers do exactly the same, is anything to be fixed on this bug, or it can be closed?

comments.author: dbaron@dbaron.org
comments.creator: dbaron@dbaron.org
comments.text: If it matches both other browsers and the spec (CSS 2.1, probably), then it can be, but if all browsers agree but the spec disagrees then we still need to get the spec fixed.
comments.raw_text: If it matches both other browsers and the spec (CSS 2.1, probably), then it can be, but if all browsers agree but the spec disagrees then we still need to get the spec fixed.
